Construction of a new athletic and social center on the
Homewood Campus of The Johns Hopkins University has
been authorized by the Board of Trustees and will be ready
for use in about a year and a half, it was announced today
by President Milton S. Eisenhower.
Preliminary drawings by the architectural firm of
Meyer and Ayers have been approved by the trustees. The
center will contain two swimming pools, one of standard
collegiate size and a training pool; handball and squash
courts; fencing and wrestling rooms; and gymnasium space
for basketball, gymnastics, and other indoor sports. The
building will also contain locker room facilities, meeting
rooms, classrooms, offices, lounge room, trophy room, and
areas for casual recreation.
The new structure will be built around the present
gymnasium, which was constructed in 1934. The university
has had plans for modernization and expansion of this
facility since 1946. The project is one of the major items
in the ten-year $76,380,000 development program of The
Johns Hopkins Fund. Construction of the center will start
in six months.
"Final plans and specifications will not he ready for
some months," Doctor Eisenhower said. "Gifts and pledges
made anonymously assure us that adequate funds will be
available by the time construction begins."
The project will add substantially to the social program of the university, especially for undergraduate
students, President Eisenhower indicated. Floor space on
the first floor will be nearly three times the present gymnasium area, and thus will provide ample space for dances
and other student social affairs. Refreshment facilities will
he available, and rooms in the area of the main foyer can
be used for non-athletic recreation, meetings, and the like.
The gap in the Homewood Field grandstand will he
filled in, and rest-room facilities for spectators will be
built underneath the stands.
"Athletic competition, physical education, recreation
and social activities are essential to any well-rounded collegiate program," Doctor Eisenhower said. "It is gratifying
to me that we can now go ahead at once with this project."
He said that the building of the new center does not
imply any change in traditional Hopkins policies governing
intercollegiate athletics. The university does not give
athletic scholarships, charges no admission for its home
games, and views athletics as a recreational and educational
activity.
shall continue to follow these policies," Doctor
Eisenhower said, "but with the new facilities we can,
happily, provide a fuller program of athletics and physical
education for students. I anticipate that we will have a more
vigorous program of intramural competition. We will be
able to expand physical education course offerings, and to
provide more casual play and recreational opportunities."
Doctor Eisenhower explained that the land for m of
the site of the present gymnasium permits excavation underneath to provide locker rooms and other auxiliary
facilities, and allows outside light and ventilation for all
interior sports rooms. The swimming pools will be in a
large wing on the south, overlooking the present soccer field.
A new main entrance on the east will lead into a large lounge
area and foyer, flanked by the trophy room and offices.
"I can think of nothing that will give more of a lift
to the morale of our students than this new facility. it is a
matter of key importance to the social and recreational
welfare of our undergraduates," Doctor Eisenhower concluded.

Ceylonese To Dance At Shriver
The Ceylon National Dancers, recently called
"one of the most brilliantly exotic dance groups
that have ever visited this country" by art-minded

the Johns Hopkins YMCA and Cosmopolitan Club.
Ceylon dances are regarded as probably the
most ancient form of "theatre" in the world, going
back to the nearly extinct Veddahs, the aboriginal
inhabitants of ancient Ceylon. All have roots in
animal worship, and thus are rich in animal characteriations.
Included in the repertoire of the three women
and six men are a fire dance, drum-battle, and
dances depicting hawks, elephants, peacocks and
swans. The costumes to be worn will be elaborate,
including harnesses of silver jewelry, golden headdresses and bracelets studded with gems.

Construction Begun On New Physics Wing

$2.5 million addition to Rowland
Hall, the physics building, on
The Johns Hopkins University
Homewood Campus. The fivelevel wing, which will more than

floor space. Half of the cost of

North Charles Street which now
serves as an administrative
building for the University.

nearby Maryland Hall, thus enclosing a portion of the lower
quadrangle. Pedestrian access
through that area of the campus
will be provided by a wide corridor in the building.

Construction of a new athletic and social center on the
Homewood Campus of The Johns Hopkins University has
been authorized by the Board of Trustees and will be ready
for use in about a year and a half, it was announced today
by President Milton S. Eisenhower.
Preliminary drawings by the architectural firm of
Meyer and Ayers have been approved by the trustees. The
center will contain two swimming pools, one of standard
collegiate size and a training pool; handball and squash
courts; fencing and wrestling rooms; and gymnasium space
for basketball, gymnastics, and other indoor sports. The
building will also contain locker room facilities, meeting
rooms, classrooms, offices, lounge room, trophy room, and
areas for casual recreation.
The new structure will be built around the present
gymnasium, which was constructed in 1934. The university
has had plans for modernization and expansion of this
facility since 1946. The project is one of the major items
in the ten-year $76,380,000 development program of The
Johns Hopkins Fund. Construction of the center will start
in six months.
"Final plans and specifications will not he ready for
some months," Doctor Eisenhower said. "Gifts and pledges
made anonymously assure us that adequate funds will be
available by the time construction begins."
The project will add substantially to the social program of the university, especially for undergraduate
students, President Eisenhower indicated. Floor space on
the first floor will be nearly three times the present gymnasium area, and thus will provide ample space for dances
and other student social affairs. Refreshment facilities will
he available, and rooms in the area of the main foyer can
be used for non-athletic recreation, meetings, and the like.
The gap in the Homewood Field grandstand will he
filled in, and rest-room facilities for spectators will be
built underneath the stands.
"Athletic competition, physical education, recreation
and social activities are essential to any well-rounded collegiate program," Doctor Eisenhower said. "It is gratifying
to me that we can now go ahead at once with this project."
He said that the building of the new center does not
imply any change in traditional Hopkins policies governing
intercollegiate athletics. The university does not give
athletic scholarships, charges no admission for its home
games, and views athletics as a recreational and educational
activity.
